User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the ScriptScribbler application.

authorId.description: Reference to the User who created the script. (Relationship: User 1:N Script)

createdAt.description: Timestamp indicating when the script was created.

lastModified.description: Timestamp indicating when the script was last modified.

Scene.title: Scene
Scene.description: Represents a scene within a script.

scriptId.description: Reference to the Script this scene belongs to. (Relationship: Script 1:N Scene)

sceneNumber.description: The scene number within the script.

content.description: The content of the scene (e.g., scene description, dialogue).

estimatedDuration.description: Estimated duration of the scene in minutes.

Character.title: Character
Character.description: Represents a character in a screenplay.

scriptId.description: Reference to the Script this character belongs to. (Relationship: Script 1:N Character)

description.description: Description of the character (e.g., personality, appearance).

Collaboration.title: Collaboration
Collaboration.description: Represents a collaboration session for a script.

id.description: Unique identifier for the collaboration session.

scriptId.description: Reference to the Script being collaborated on. (Relationship: Script 1:N Collaboration)

userId.description: Reference to the User participating in the collaboration. (Relationship: User 1:N Collaboration)

role.description: Role of the user in the collaboration (e.g., writer, editor, viewer).

permissions.description: Permissions granted to the user in the collaboration (e.g., edit, view, comment).

SceneCharacter.title: SceneCharacter
SceneCharacter.description: Represents the relationship between a scene and characters appearing in it.  This is an N:N join table between Scene and Character

id.description: Unique identifier for the scene character relationship.

sceneId.description: Reference to the Scene. (Relationship: Scene N:N Character)

characterId.description: Reference to the Character. (Relationship: Character N:N Scene)

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to ensure security, scalability, and debuggability, following the principles of Authorization Independence, Clarity of Intent, DBAC (Database-Based Access Control), and QAPs (Rules are not Filters). It leverages denormalization, structural segregation, and consistent access modeling.

**Authorization Independence:**

*   Authorization data (e.g., roles, members) is denormalized into subcollections or documents where necessary. For instance, the `Collaboration` entity stores `userId` and `role` within the document itself, removing the need to fetch user roles from a separate location. This allows atomic operations (transactions/batches) without relying on parent data.

**Structural Segregation:**

*   The structure segregates data based on access needs. User-specific data (scripts) are stored under `/users/{userId}/scripts/{scriptId}`, while collaborative data is stored in `/scripts/{scriptId}/collaborations/{collaborationId}`. This prevents mixing data with different access requirements in the same collection.

**Access Modeling:**

*   **Path-Based Ownership:** User-owned scripts are stored under `/users/{userId}/scripts/{scriptId}`, which provides a clear ownership model.
*   **Membership Map (Collaborations):** The `Collaboration` entity includes `userId` and `role` fields directly, acting as a membership map. This provides explicit information of which users have certain access or roles.

**QAPs (Rules are not Filters):**

*   The structure supports secure `list` operations by ensuring that each collection has a homogeneous security posture. Rules can be written to allow listing only documents that the user has access to, based on path-based ownership or membership maps.
